column2: Piccadilly, February 19th, 1801.
column3: Piccadilly, february nineteenth eighteen o one.

column2: MY DEAR LORD,
column3: MY DEAR LORD,

column2: Whether Emma will be able to write to you to-day, or not, is a question; as she has got one of her terrible sick head-achs.
column3: Whether Emma will be able to write to you to day, or not, is a question; as she has got one of her terrible sick head a c h s.

column2: Among other things that vex her, is--that we have been drawn in to be under the absolute necessity of giving a dinner to ****** on Sunday next. He asked it himself; having expressed his strong desire of hearing Banti's and Emma's voices together.
column3: Among other things that vex her, is-that we have been drawn in to be under the absolute necessity of giving a dinner to asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk on Sunday next. He asked it himself; having expressed his strong desire of hearing Banti's and Emma's voices together.

column2: I am well aware of the danger that would attend ******* frequenting our house.
column3: I am well aware of the danger that would attend asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk frequenting our house.

column2: Not that I fear, that Emma could ever be induced to act contrary to the prudent conduct she has hitherto pursued; but the world is so ill-natured, that the worst construction is put upon the most innocent actions.
column3: Not that I fear, that Emma could ever be induced to act contrary to the prudent conduct she has hitherto pursued; but the world is so ill natured, that the worst construction is put upon the most innocent actions.

column2: As this dinner must be, or ****** would be offended, I shall keep it strictly to the musical part; invite only Banti, her husband, and Taylor; and, as I wish to shew a civility to Davison, I have sent him an invitation.
column3: As this dinner must be, or asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk would be offended, I shall keep it strictly to the musical part; invite only Banti, her husband, and Taylor; and, as I wish to shew a civility to Davison, I have sent him an invitation.

column2: In short, we will get rid of it as well as we can, and guard against its producing more meetings of the same sort.
column3: In short, we will get rid of it as well as we can, and guard against its producing more meetings of the same sort.

column2: Emma would really have gone any lengths, to have avoided Sunday's dinner.
column3: Emma would really have gone any lengths, to have avoided Sunday's dinner.

column2: But I thought it would not be prudent to break with ******; who, really, has shewn the greatest civility to us, when we were last in England, and since we returned: and she has, at last, acquiesced to my opinion.
column3: But I thought it would not be prudent to break with asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk asterisk; who, really, has shewn the greatest civility to us, when we were last in England, and since we returned: and she has, at last, acquiesced to my opinion.

column2: I have been thus explicit, as I know well your Lordship's way of thinking; and your very kind attachment to us, and to every thing that concerns us.
column3: I have been thus explicit, as I know well your Lordship's way of thinking; and your very kind attachment to us, and to every thing that concerns us.

column2: The King caught cold at the Chapel the other day, and there was no levee yesterday; and, to-day, the Queen alone will be at the drawing-room: and, I believe, the new ministry will not be quite fixed, until the levee-day next week.
column3: The King caught cold at the Chapel the other day, and there was no levee yesterday; and, to day, the Queen alone will be at the drawing room: and, I believe, the new ministry will not be quite fixed, until the levee day next week.

column2: As to my business--I have done all I can to bring it to a point.
column3: As to my business-I have done all I can to bring it to a point.

column2: The pension recommended by Lord Grenville was only like Walpole's--a nominal two thousand pounds.
column3: The pension recommended by Lord Grenville was only like Walpole's-a nominal two thousand pounds.

column2: I have represented the injustice of that--after my having had the King's promise of not being removed from Naples, but at my own request; and having only empowered Lord Grenville to remove me, on securing to me a nett income of two thousand pounds per annum.
column3: I have represented the injustice of that-after my having had the King's promise of not being removed from Naples, but at my own request; and having only empowered Lord Grenville to remove me, on securing to me a nett income of two thousand pounds per annum.

column2: Lord Grenville has recommended to the Treasury, the taking my extraordinary expences into consideration.
column3: Lord Grenville has recommended to the Treasury, the taking my extraordinary expences into consideration.

column2: I have fully demonstrated, to Lord Grenville and Treasury, that eight thousand pounds is absolutely necessary for the clearing off my unfunded debt, without making up for my losses.
column3: I have fully demonstrated, to Lord Grenville and Treasury, that eight thousand pounds is absolutely necessary for the clearing off my unfunded debt, without making up for my losses.

column2: Upon the whole, then, I do not expect to get more than the nett annuity above mentioned, and the eight thousand pounds.
column3: Upon the whole, then, I do not expect to get more than the nett annuity above mentioned, and the eight thousand pounds.

column2: But, unless that is granted, I shall, indeed, have been very ill-used!
column3: But, unless that is granted, I shall, indeed, have been very ill used!

column2: I hope, in my next, to be able to inform your Lordship that all has been finally settled.
column3: I hope, in my next, to be able to inform your Lordship that all has been finally settled.

column2: I am busy in putting in order the remains of my vases and pictures, that you so kindly saved for me on board the Fourdroyant; and the sale of them will enable me to go on more at my ease, and not leave a debt unpaid.
column3: I am busy in putting in order the remains of my vases and pictures, that you so kindly saved for me on board the Fourdroyant; and the sale of them will enable me to go on more at my ease, and not leave a debt unpaid.

column2: But, unfortunately, there have been too many picture sales this year, and mine will come late.
column3: But, unfortunately, there have been too many picture sales this year, and mine will come late.

column2: Adieu! my very dear Lord.
column3: Adieu! my very dear Lord.

column2: May health and success attend you, wherever you go!
column3: May health and success attend you, wherever you go!

column2: And, I flatter myself, this political jumble may hasten a peace, and bring you back soon.
column3: And, I flatter myself, this political jumble may hasten a peace, and bring you back soon.

column2: Your Lordship's ever obliged, and most sincerely attached, friend and servant,
column3: Your Lordship's ever obliged, and most sincerely attached, friend and servant,

column2: Wm.
column3: w m.

column2: HAMILTON.
column3: HAMILTON.

column2: VIII.
column3: eight.

column2: Piccadilly, February 20th, 1801.
column3: Piccadilly, february twentieth eighteen o one.

column2: MY DEAR LORD,
column3: MY DEAR LORD,

column2: You need not be the least alarmed, that Emma has commissioned me to send you the newspapers; and write you a line, to tell you that she is much better--having vomited naturally, and is now purposing to take a regular one of tartar emetic.
column3: You need not be the least alarmed, that Emma has commissioned me to send you the newspapers; and write you a line, to tell you that she is much better-having vomited naturally, and is now purposing to take a regular one of tartar emetic.

column2: All her convulsive complaints certainly proceed from a foul stomach; and I will answer for it, she will be in spirits to write to you herself to-morrow.
column3: All her convulsive complaints certainly proceed from a foul stomach; and I will answer for it, she will be in spirits to write to you herself to morrow.

column2: Adieu! my very dear Lord.
column3: Adieu! my very dear Lord.

column2: I have not a moment to lose, as the bell is going.
column3: I have not a moment to lose, as the bell is going.

column2: Your ever attached and obliged humble servant,
column3: Your ever attached and obliged humble servant,

column2: Wm.
column3: w m.

column2: HAMILTON.
column3: HAMILTON.

column2: IX.
column3: IX.

column2: Piccadilly, March 7th, 1801.
column3: Piccadilly, march seventh eighteen o one.

column2: MY VERY DEAR LORD,
column3: MY VERY DEAR LORD,

column2: I wish it was in my power to profit of your kind invitation; you would soon see me and Emma on board the St. George: but I am now totally occupied in preparing for the sale of my pictures, and what I have saved of my vases.
column3: I wish it was in my power to profit of your kind invitation; you would soon see me and Emma on board the saint George: but I am now totally occupied in preparing for the sale of my pictures, and what I have saved of my vases.

column2: To my great satisfaction, I have found some of the most capital vases; and which I thought, surely, lost on board the Colossus.
column3: To my great satisfaction, I have found some of the most capital vases; and which I thought, surely, lost on board the Colossus.

column2: It has comforted me much.
column3: It has comforted me much.

column2: We remain in the same cruel state with respect to the King's recovery. There can be no doubt, but that his Majesty is better.
column3: We remain in the same cruel state with respect to the King's recovery. There can be no doubt, but that his Majesty is better.

column2: However, if my conjectures are true, the Regency must soon take place: as it may be long before his Majesty could be troubled with business, supposing even his _fever_ to have totally subsided; and, the times admit of no delays.
column3: However, if my conjectures are true, the Regency must soon take place: as it may be long before his Majesty could be troubled with business, supposing even his underscore fever underscore to have totally subsided; and, the times admit of no delays.

column2: We see, now, the certainty of the French squadron's being in the Mediterranean.
column3: We see, now, the certainty of the French squadron's being in the Mediterranean.

column2: God knows, how all this will end!
column3: God knows, how all this will end!

column2: But I hope it will be your Lordship's lot to bring Paul to his senses.
column3: But I hope it will be your Lordship's lot to bring Paul to his senses.

column2: God send you every success; and send you home, safe and well, crowned with additional laurels!
column3: God send you every success; and send you home, safe and well, crowned with additional laurels!

column2: And then, I hope, you will repose your shattered frame; and make your friends happy, by staying with them.
column3: And then, I hope, you will repose your shattered frame; and make your friends happy, by staying with them.

column2: Emma
column3: Emma

column2: Emma is certainly much better, but not quite free from bile.
column3: Emma is certainly much better, but not quite free from bile.

column2: Ever, my dear Lord, your Lordship's most attached, and eternally obliged, humble servant,
column3: Ever, my dear Lord, your Lordship's most attached, and eternally obliged, humble servant,

column2: Wm.
column3: w m.

column2: HAMILTON.
column3: HAMILTON.

column2: X.
column3: X.

column2: Piccadilly, April 16th, 1801.
column3: Piccadilly, april sixteenth eighteen o one.

column2: What can I say, my Dear Lord! that would convey the smallest idea of what we felt yesterday, on receiving the authentic letters confirming your late most glorious victory: and read, in your own hand, that God had not only granted you complete success against the enemies of our country; but, in the midst of such perils, prevented your receiving the smallest scratch!
column3: What can I say, my Dear Lord! that would convey the smallest idea of what we felt yesterday, on receiving the authentic letters confirming your late most glorious victory: and read, in your own hand, that God had not only granted you complete success against the enemies of our country; but, in the midst of such perils, prevented your receiving the smallest scratch!

column2: We can only repeat what we knew well, and often said, before--that Nelson _was_, _is_, and to the _last_ will ever be, _the first_.
column3: We can only repeat what we knew well, and often said, before-that Nelson underscore was underscore, underscore is underscore, and to the underscore last underscore will ever be, underscore the first underscore.

column2: However, we all agree that, when we get you safe home once more--that you should never more risk your shattered frame.
column3: However, we all agree that, when we get you safe home once more-that you should never more risk your shattered frame.

column2: You have done enough, and are well entitled to the motto of Virgil--
column3: You have done enough, and are well entitled to the motto of Virgil-

column2: _Hic Victor caestus artemque repono_.
column3: underscore Hic Victor caestus artemque repono underscore.

column2: The famous Broughton, after he had beaten every opponent, that dared to measure hard blows with him, set up an ale-house--the Broughton's Head--in London, with the above verse of Virgil under it.
column3: The famous Broughton, after he had beaten every opponent, that dared to measure hard blows with him, set up an ale house-the Broughton's Head-in London, with the above verse of Virgil under it.

column2: Some years after, he was persuaded to accept the challenge of a coachman, and was beaten.
column3: Some years after, he was persuaded to accept the challenge of a coachman, and was beaten.

column2: Not that I mean to convey, that any such thing could happen to your Lordship; but, you have done enough.
column3: Not that I mean to convey, that any such thing could happen to your Lordship; but, you have done enough.

column2: Let others follow your examples; they will be remembered to the latest posterity.
column3: Let others follow your examples; they will be remembered to the latest posterity.

column2: It appeared to me most extraordinary, that the 6th inst. the date of your last letter to Emma, the death of the Emperor Paul (which we have no doubt of here) should not be known at Copenhagen!
column3: It appeared to me most extraordinary, that the sixth inst. the date of your last letter to Emma, the death of the Emperor Paul (which we have no doubt of here) should not be known at Copenhagen!

column2: It appears to us that, as soon as that great event is known in Sweden and Denmark, with the severe blow you have just given the latter, the formidable giant, Northern Coalition, will of itself fall to pieces; and that we shall have the happiness of embracing you again here, in a very short time.
column3: It appears to us that, as soon as that great event is known in Sweden and Denmark, with the severe blow you have just given the latter, the formidable giant, Northern Coalition, will of itself fall to pieces; and that we shall have the happiness of embracing you again here, in a very short time.

column2: You would have laughed to have seen what I saw yesterday!
column3: You would have laughed to have seen what I saw yesterday!

column2: _Emma_ did not know whether she was on her head or heels--in such a hurry to tell your great news, that she could utter nothing but tears of joy and tenderness.
column3: underscore Emma underscore did not know whether she was on her head or heels-in such a hurry to tell your great news, that she could utter nothing but tears of joy and tenderness.

column2: I went to Davison yesterday morning; and found him still in bed, having had a severe fit of the gout, and with your letter, which he had just received: and he cried like a child!
column3: I went to Davison yesterday morning; and found him still in bed, having had a severe fit of the gout, and with your letter, which he had just received: and he cried like a child!

column2: But, what was very extraordinary, assured me that, from the instant he had read your letter, all pain had left him, and that he felt himself able to get up and walk about.
column3: But, what was very extraordinary, assured me that, from the instant he had read your letter, all pain had left him, and that he felt himself able to get up and walk about.

column2: Your brother, Mrs. Nelson, and Horace, dined with us.
column3: Your brother, mrs Nelson, and Horace, dined with us.

column2: Your brother was more extraordinary than ever.
column3: Your brother was more extraordinary than ever.

column2: He would get up suddenly, and cut a caper; rubbing his hands every time that the thought of your fresh laurels came into his head.
column3: He would get up suddenly, and cut a caper; rubbing his hands every time that the thought of your fresh laurels came into his head.

column2: In short, except myself, (and your Lordship knows that I have some phlegm) all the company, which was considerable, after dinner--the Duke, Lord William, Mr. Este, &c.--were mad with joy.
column3: In short, except myself, (and your Lordship knows that I have some phlegm) all the company, which was considerable, after dinner-the Duke, Lord William, mr Este, and c.--were mad with joy.

column2: But, I am sure, that no one really rejoiced more, at heart, than I did.
column3: But, I am sure, that no one really rejoiced more, at heart, than I did.

column2: I have lived too long to have _extacies_!
column3: I have lived too long to have underscore extacies underscore!

column2: But, with calm reflection, I felt for my friend having got to the very summit of glory!--the "_Ne plus ultra!_"--that he has had another opportunity of rendering his country the most important service; and manifesting, again, his judgment, his intrepidity, and humanity.
column3: But, with calm reflection, I felt for my friend having got to the very summit of glory!--the "underscore Ne plus ultra!underscore"--that he has had another opportunity of rendering his country the most important service; and manifesting, again, his judgment, his intrepidity, and humanity.

column2: God bless you, my very dear Lord, and send you soon home to your friends.
column3: God bless you, my very dear Lord, and send you soon home to your friends.

column2: Enemies you have none, but those that are bursting with envy; and such animals infest all parts of the world.
column3: Enemies you have none, but those that are bursting with envy; and such animals infest all parts of the world.

column2: The King, be assured, is (though weak) getting well fast.
column3: The King, be assured, is (though weak) getting well fast.

column2: Lord Loughborough told Livingston, who has just been here, that he was with the King the day before yesterday, before and after delivery of the seals, and that he was perfectly calm and recollected.
column3: Lord Loughborough told Livingston, who has just been here, that he was with the King the day before yesterday, before and after delivery of the seals, and that he was perfectly calm and recollected.

column2: Ever your sincerely attached, and truly obliged, humble servant,
column3: Ever your sincerely attached, and truly obliged, humble servant,

column2: Wm.
column3: w m.

column2: HAMILTON.
column3: HAMILTON.

column2: XI.
column3: XI.

column2: Milford, August 12th, 1801.
column3: Milford, august twelfth eighteen o one.

column2: MY DEAR LORD,
column3: MY DEAR LORD,

column2: Emma has constantly given me every possible intelligence relative to your Lordship, and the important operations you are about at this most interesting moment.
column3: Emma has constantly given me every possible intelligence relative to your Lordship, and the important operations you are about at this most interesting moment.

column2: You have already calmed the minds of every body with respect to the threatened French invasion.
column3: You have already calmed the minds of every body with respect to the threatened French invasion.

column2: In short, all your Lordship does is complete; like yourself, and nobody else.
column3: In short, all your Lordship does is complete; like yourself, and nobody else.

column2: But still, I think, there is no occasion for the Commander in Chief to expose his person as much as you do.
column3: But still, I think, there is no occasion for the Commander in Chief to expose his person as much as you do.

column2: Why should you not have a private flag, known to your fleet and not to the enemy, when you shift it and go reconnoitring?
column3: Why should you not have a private flag, known to your fleet and not to the enemy, when you shift it and go reconnoitring?

column2: Captain Hopkins, going from hence in the Speedwell cutter to join your Lordship, will be happy to introduce himself to you by presenting this letter himself.
column3: Captain Hopkins, going from hence in the Speedwell cutter to join your Lordship, will be happy to introduce himself to you by presenting this letter himself.

column2: They give him a good character in this country, but my acquaintance with him is but of two days.
column3: They give him a good character in this country, but my acquaintance with him is but of two days.

column2: I was yesterday with Captain Dobbins, in the Diligence cutter.
column3: I was yesterday with Captain Dobbins, in the Diligence cutter.

column2: We sailed out of this glorious harbour; and, the day being fine, sailed out some leagues, and examined the Crow Rock, which is reckoned the greatest danger as to entering the harbour.
column3: We sailed out of this glorious harbour; and, the day being fine, sailed out some leagues, and examined the Crow Rock, which is reckoned the greatest danger as to entering the harbour.

column2: But the two light-houses lately erected take off all danger in the night; and [it] is visible in the day-time, except a short time in spring tides.
column3: But the two light houses lately erected take off all danger in the night; and [it] is visible in the day-time, except a short time in spring tides.

column2: I am delighted with the improvements at Milford.
column3: I am delighted with the improvements at Milford.

column2: It will surely be a great town, if we have peace, in three years; the houses rising up, like mushrooms, even in these difficult times.
column3: It will surely be a great town, if we have peace, in three years; the houses rising up, like mushrooms, even in these difficult times.

column2: We allow any one to build--at their own expence--at an easy ground-rent, and to fall in at the expiration of three lives, or sixty years.
column3: We allow any one to build-at their own expence-at an easy ground rent, and to fall in at the expiration of three lives, or sixty years.

column2: You may judge that, having two thousand acres all round the town, these inhabitants will want land for cows and horses, and gardens, &c. and, of course, I must be a gainer in the end.
column3: You may judge that, having two thousand acres all round the town, these inhabitants will want land for cows and horses, and gardens, and c. and, of course, I must be a gainer in the end.

column2: I visited the two light-houses, and found them perfectly clean, and in good order: and I never could conceive the brilliant light that they give; one has sixteen reflected lights, and the other ten.
column3: I visited the two light houses, and found them perfectly clean, and in good order: and I never could conceive the brilliant light that they give; one has sixteen reflected lights, and the other ten.

column2: To-day, I go upon my last visit to Lord Milford; and, on Saturday, set out for Piccadilly: and where I am not without hopes of meeting your Lordship; as I think, in the manner you dispatch business, you will have completed all by Wednesday next, the day I shall probably be in London.
column3: To day, I go upon my last visit to Lord Milford; and, on Saturday, set out for Piccadilly: and where I am not without hopes of meeting your Lordship; as I think, in the manner you dispatch business, you will have completed all by Wednesday next, the day I shall probably be in London.

column2: Charles Greville's kind compliments.
column3: Charles Greville's kind compliments.

column2: The name of Nelson is in every mouth; and, indeed, we owe every thing to your judgment and exertions.
column3: The name of Nelson is in every mouth; and, indeed, we owe every thing to your judgment and exertions.

column2: Adieu!
column3: Adieu!

column2: God bless you.
column3: God bless you.

column2: Ever your Lordship's affectionate friend, and obliged humble servant,
column3: Ever your Lordship's affectionate friend, and obliged humble servant,

column2: Wm.
column3: w m.

column2: HAMILTON.
column3: HAMILTON.

column2: XII.
column3: twelve.

column2: Piccadilly, April 28th, 1802.
column3: Piccadilly, april twenty eighth eighteen o two.

column2: MY DEAR LORD,
column3: MY DEAR LORD,

column2: Emma says--I must write a letter to you, of condolence for the heavy loss your Lordship has suffered.
column3: Emma says-I must write a letter to you, of condolence for the heavy loss your Lordship has suffered.

column2: When persons, in the prime of life, are carried off by accidents or sickness--or what is, I believe, oftener the case, by the ignorance and mistakes of the physicians--then, indeed, there is reason to lament!
column3: When persons, in the prime of life, are carried off by accidents or sickness-or what is, I believe, oftener the case, by the ignorance and mistakes of the physicians-then, indeed, there is reason to lament!

column2: But as, in the case of your good Father, the lamp was suffered to burn out fairly, and that his sufferings were not great; and that, by his Son's glorious and unparalleled successes, he saw his family ennobled, and with the probability, in time, of its being amply rewarded, as it ought to have been long ago--his mind could not be troubled, in his latter moments, on account of the family he left behind him: and, as to his own peace of mind, at the moment of his dissolution, there can be no doubt, among those who ever had the honour of his acquaintance.
column3: But as, in the case of your good Father, the lamp was suffered to burn out fairly, and that his sufferings were not great; and that, by his Son's glorious and unparalleled successes, he saw his family ennobled, and with the probability, in time, of its being amply rewarded, as it ought to have been long ago-his mind could not be troubled, in his latter moments, on account of the family he left behind him: and, as to his own peace of mind, at the moment of his dissolution, there can be no doubt, among those who ever had the honour of his acquaintance.

column2: I have said more than I intended; but dare say, your Lordship had nearly the same thoughts--with the addition of the feelings of a dutiful Son, for the loss of a most excellent Father.
column3: I have said more than I intended; but dare say, your Lordship had nearly the same thoughts-with the addition of the feelings of a dutiful Son, for the loss of a most excellent Father.

column2: It is, however, now--as your Lordship is the Father of your Family--incumbent upon you to take particular care of your own health. Nay, you are, by the voice of the nation, its first prop and support.
column3: It is, however, now-as your Lordship is the Father of your Family-incumbent upon you to take particular care of your own health. Nay, you are, by the voice of the nation, its first prop and support.

column2: Keep up your spirits; and, that you may long enjoy your well-earned honours, is the sincere wish of your Lordship's affectionate friend, and attached humble servant,
column3: Keep up your spirits; and, that you may long enjoy your well earned honours, is the sincere wish of your Lordship's affectionate friend, and attached humble servant,
